DataElement.preferredName: Image Series Modality DICOM Modality Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A system of categories for representing a specific manner, characteristic, pattern of a data acquisition device used in an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The type of data acquisition device used in an imaging event whether physical or electronic.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.:A number of things or events standing or succeeding in order, and connected by a like relation. (from On-line Medical Dictionary)

Concepts.definition: Any record of an imaging event whether physical or electronic.
A group or succession of objects, substances, or events arranged in regular order in space or time, connected by a like relation, or forming a kind of chain.

Property.preferredDefinition: A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition.

Concepts.definition: A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

DataElementConcept.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine
DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 4/30/09 created per VCDE Equipment CDE set small group to include "image" as a qualifier in the OC.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The kind of imaging equipment used to complete an imaging event whether physical or electronic.  [Manually-curated]_A comprehensive set of standards for communications between medical imaging devices, including handling, storing and transmitting information in medical imaging. It includes a file format definition and a network communication protocol._A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Photography used to study and document structures and disorders of the eye.

Concepts.definition: Photography used to study and document structures and disorders of the eye.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An independent DICOM SOP Instance that contains information on how a particular image should be displayed. The Presentation State may contain label information (types of Label and Positions), windowing values, zoom value, scrolling (panning) values, rotations or any other visual display element that is defined within the DICOM standard.

Concepts.definition: An independent DICOM SOP Instance that contains information on how a particular image should be displayed. The Presentation State may contain label information (types of Label and Positions), windowing values, zoom value, scrolling (panning) values, rotations or any other visual display element that is defined within the DICOM standard.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A panoramic or wide-view x-ray of the upper and lower jaw and teeth.

Concepts.definition: A panoramic or wide-view x-ray of the upper and lower jaw and teeth.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Examination of the tissues and deep structures of the body by x-ray, using the fluoroscope, a device that produces an image when x-rays strike a fluorescent screen.

Concepts.definition: Examination of the tissues and deep structures of the body by x-ray, using the fluoroscope, a device that produces an image when x-rays strike a fluorescent screen.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

Concepts.definition: A radiographic procedure using the emission of x-rays to form an image of the structure penetrated by the radiation.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The amount of radiation administered during a therapy session.

Concepts.definition: The amount of radiation administered during a therapy session.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.

Concepts.definition: An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The design for radiation therapy.

Concepts.definition: The design for radiation therapy.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A record generated from radiation therapy.

Concepts.definition: A record generated from radiation therapy.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An object of the DICOM standard used for the transfer of patient structures and related data defined on CT scanners, virtual simulation workstations, treatment planning systems and similar devices.

Concepts.definition: An object of the DICOM standard used for the transfer of patient structures and related data defined on CT scanners, virtual simulation workstations, treatment planning systems and similar devices.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Microscopy that uses a sample affixed to a slide.

Concepts.definition: Microscopy that uses a sample affixed to a slide.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Pairs of images that may be viewed together in stereo.

Concepts.definition: Pairs of images that may be viewed together in stereo.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A document type consisting of a document header and a document body.

Concepts.definition: A document type consisting of a document header and a document body.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of tomography in which gamma photon-emitting radionuclides are administered to the patient and then detected by one or more gamma cameras rotated around the patient. From the series of two-dimensional images produced, a three-dimensional image can be created by computer reconstruction.

Concepts.definition: A type of tomography in which gamma photon-emitting radionuclides are administered to the patient and then detected by one or more gamma cameras rotated around the patient. From the series of two-dimensional images produced, a three-dimensional image can be created by computer reconstruction.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Computed tomography that describes temperature details across a surface.

Concepts.definition: Computed tomography that describes temperature details across a surface.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that use non-invasive measurements to map biologically-generated magnetic fields.

Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that use non-invasive measurements to map biologically-generated magnetic fields.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of an angioscope to view the interior of a blood vessel.

Concepts.definition: The use of an angioscope to view the interior of a blood vessel.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The process of recording sound to a storage device.

Concepts.definition: The process of recording sound to a storage device.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of pulsed ultrasound to visualize blood flow through blood vessels. Flow direction and speed are shown in differing colors.

Concepts.definition: The use of pulsed ultrasound to visualize blood flow through blood vessels. Flow direction and speed are shown in differing colors.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Cinefluorography (retired)
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 11/16/22 Retired per CRDC DSS. Per latest DICOM PS3.16 2022c, CF modality replaced by RF, DCM, Radiofluoroscopy. mr;

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Endoscopic examination of the uterine cervix and vagina.

Concepts.definition: Endoscopic examination of the uterine cervix and vagina.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: X-ray imaging that replaces film with a phosphor imaging plate to create a digital image.

Concepts.definition: X-ray imaging that replaces film with a phosphor imaging plate to create a digital image.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique in which high-frequency sound waves are bounced off internal organs and the echo pattern is converted into a 2 dimensional picture of the structures beneath the transducer.

Concepts.definition: The use of high-frequency sound waves to generate images of the body.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Videofluorography (retired)
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 11/16/22 Retired per CRDC DSS. Per latest DICOM PS3.16 2022c, VF modality replaced by RF, DCM, Radiofluoroscopy. mr;

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The X-ray examination of the blood vessels or chambers of the heart.

Concepts.definition: Any nuclear medicine study that utilizes a radioactive tracer to image blood vessels or characterize blood flow.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Photographic image acquisition using a camera mounted externally from the subject.

Concepts.definition: Photographic image acquisition using a camera mounted externally from the subject.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Endoscopic examination of the urinary bladder or urethra.

Concepts.definition: Endoscopic examination of the urinary bladder or urethra.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method of examining body organs by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

Concepts.definition: A method of examining structures within the body by scanning them with X rays and using a computer to construct a series of cross-sectional scans along a single axis.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An ultrasound technique that uses a B-mode transducer to visualize blood flow and a Doppler probe to assess velocity and direction of the blood flow.

Concepts.definition: An ultrasound technique that uses a B-mode transducer to visualize blood flow and a Doppler probe to assess velocity and direction of the blood flow.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Digital fluoroscopy (retired)
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 11/16/22 Retired per CRDC DSS. Per latest DICOM PS3.16 2022c, DF modality replaced by replaced by RF, DCM, Radiofluoroscopy. mr

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Examination of a body part by transillumination.

Concepts.definition: Examination of a body part by transillumination.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Microscopy that uses a digital camera instead of eyepieces. The microscope is connected to a computer monitor and images are obtained in real time.

Concepts.definition: Microscopy that uses a digital camera instead of eyepieces. The microscope is connected to a computer monitor and images are obtained in real time.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Digital Subtraction Angiography (retired)
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 11/16/22 Retired per CRDC DSS. Per latest DICOM PS3.16 2022c, DS modality replaced by XA, DCM, X-Ray Angiography. mr

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Acquisition or display of radiographic images using digital techniques.

Concepts.definition: Acquisition or display of radiographic images using digital techniques.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that uses ultrasonic waves directed over the chest wall to obtain a graphic record of the heart's position, motion of the walls, or internal parts such as the valves.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that uses high-frequency sound waves (ultrasound) to create an image of the heart.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cardiac procedure performed under fluoroscopy to determine the area of the heart that is the source of aberrant electrical impulses that give rise to arrhythmias. Aberrant pathways can be terminated by ablation.

Concepts.definition: A cardiac procedure performed under fluoroscopy to determine the area of the heart that is the source of aberrant electrical impulses that give rise to arrhythmias. Aberrant pathways can be terminated by ablation.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (en-DAHS-ko-pee) The use of a thin, lighted tube (called an endoscope) to examine the inside of the body.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic or therapeutic procedure in which an endoscope is inserted in a tubular organ to examine the structural architecture and/or remove abnormal tissues.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A diagnostic procedure that uses the fluorescence of fluorescein dye to examine the blood flow in the choroid and retina.

Concepts.definition: A diagnostic procedure that uses the fluorescence of fluorescein dye to examine the blood flow in the choroid and retina.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique used to examine of the back (fundus) and other anatomical structures of the eye with a magnifying instrument.

Concepts.definition: A technique used to examine of the back (fundus) and other anatomical structures of the eye with a magnifying instrument.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of various technologies to resolve the structure or features of objects too small or fine to naturally be seen by eye.

Concepts.definition: The use of various technologies to resolve the structure or features of objects too small or fine to naturally be seen by eye.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A physical, printed version of information from a computer.

Concepts.definition: A physical, printed version of information from a computer.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The analysis of hemodynamic pressure changes to obtain diagnostic information about the function of the right and left ventricles during systole and diastole.

Concepts.definition: The analysis of hemodynamic pressure changes to obtain diagnostic information about the function of the right and left ventricles during systole and diastole.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Radiography done within the oral cavity.

Concepts.definition: Radiography done within the oral cavity.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive procedure in which sound waves (called ultrasound) are bounced off of vascular tissues from within the vessel and the echoes produce a picture (sonogram).

Concepts.definition: An invasive procedure in which sound waves (called ultrasound) are bounced off of vascular tissues from within the vessel and the echoes produce a picture (sonogram).

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Selection of a key image by the interpreting physician.

Concepts.definition: Selection of a key image by the interpreting physician.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: (lap-a-RAHS-ko-pee) The insertion of a thin, lighted tube (called a laparoscope) through the abdominal wall to inspect the inside of the abdomen and remove tissue samples.

Concepts.definition: A surgical procedure during which a laparoscope is inserted into the abdomen to view the abdominopelvic contents for diagnostic and/or therapeutic purposes.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for obtaining information about the surface morphology and topology of an object.

Concepts.definition: A method for obtaining information about the surface morphology and topology of an object.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image of blood vessels constructed using magnetic resonance imaging.

Concepts.definition: Angiography using magnetic resonance imaging.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging examination of the breast by means of x-rays.

Concepts.definition: A type of radiography used specifically to examine breast tissue. The procedure utilizes a low-dose of x-rays or radiation to generate an image. A mammography exam or mammogram, is used as a screening tool to detect early breast cancer in women experiencing no symptoms and to detect and diagnose breast disease.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

Concepts.definition: Imaging that uses radiofrequency waves and a strong magnetic field rather than x-rays to provide detailed pictures of internal organs and tissues. The technique is valuable for the diagnosis of many pathologic conditions, including cancer, heart and vascular disease, stroke, and joint and musculoskeletal disorders.

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy

PermissibleValues.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An eye examination method in which a computer-controlled electronic optometer is used to automatically measure refractive error.

Concepts.definition: An eye examination method in which a computer-controlled electronic optometer is used to automatically measure refractive error.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The results of an assessment or the content of one or more standard operating procedures (SOP) instance(s).

Concepts.definition: The results of an assessment or the content of one or more standard operating procedures (SOP) instance(s).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of quantitative ultrasound for estimating bone mineral density status of the peripheral skeleton, usually done at the heel.

Concepts.definition: The use of quantitative ultrasound for estimating bone mineral density status of the peripheral skeleton, usually done at the heel.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any method used to measure bone mineral content and density.

Concepts.definition: Any method used to measure bone mineral content and density.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The rules and procedures for computed tomography acquisition.

Concepts.definition: The rules and procedures for computed tomography acquisition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A noninvasive diagnostic procedure that allows for in vivo microscopic examination of the epidermis, the dermoepidermal junction, and the papillary dermis. This aids in the identification of specific diagnostic patterns related to color and cell structure to aid in differentiating malignant and benign lesions.

Concepts.definition: A noninvasive diagnostic procedure that allows for in vivo microscopic examination of the epidermis, the dermoepidermal junction, and the papillary dermis. This aids in the identification of specific diagnostic patterns related to color and cell structure to aid in differentiating malignant and benign lesions.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An organized collection of records that describe a particular body of data.

Concepts.definition: A physical object, or electronic counterpart, that is characterized by containing writing which is meant to be human-readable.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The neurophysiologic exploration of the electrical activity of the brain by the application of electrodes to the scalp. The resulting traces are known as an electroencephalogram (EEG). This test is used to assess brain damage, epilepsy and other problems.

Concepts.definition: The neurophysiologic exploration of the electrical activity of the brain by the application of electrodes to the scalp. The resulting traces are known as an electroencephalogram (EEG). This test is used to assess brain damage, epilepsy and other problems.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An assessment of skeletal muscle function and nerve control, obtained by recording and studying the intrinsic electrical properties of the muscles.

Concepts.definition: An assessment of skeletal muscle function and nerve control, obtained by recording and studying the intrinsic electrical properties of the muscles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An electrophysiologic test that measures the standing potential between the cornea and Bruch's membrane. Primary applications are in ophthalmological diagnosis and in recording eye movements.

Concepts.definition: An electrophysiologic test that measures the standing potential between the cornea and Bruch's membrane. Primary applications are in ophthalmological diagnosis and in recording eye movements.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A medical device placed on or inserted in an anatomic site for accurate visualization of a particular area, prior to radiation treatment or surgery. Examples include markers inserted in the prostate gland for visualization of the site affected by cancer, prior to radiation therapy; markers taped to the scalp prior to imaging in frameless stereotactic brain surgery; and femoral and tibial pins used for spatial orientation in total knee replacement.

Concepts.definition: A medical device placed on or inserted in an anatomic site for accurate visualization of a particular area, prior to radiation treatment or surgery. Examples include markers inserted in the prostate gland for visualization of the site affected by cancer, prior to radiation therapy; markers taped to the scalp prior to imaging in frameless stereotactic brain surgery; and femoral and tibial pins used for spatial orientation in total knee replacement.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Calculations made to determine the required optical power for an intra-ocular lens that will be implanted following cataract surgery. Its strength is a factor of corneal refractive power, ocular media type, and axial length.

Concepts.definition: Calculations made to determine the required optical power for an intra-ocular lens that will be implanted following cataract surgery. Its strength is a factor of corneal refractive power, ocular media type, and axial length.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Optical coherence tomography used for imaging within blood vessels.

Concepts.definition: An optical coherence tomography imaging method that utilizes motion contrast imaging to capture the patterns of moving red blood cell reflectance across time and create high-resolution, 3D angiograms of vascular networks.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The measurement of the curvature of the anterior corneal surface.

Concepts.definition: The measurement of the curvature of the anterior corneal surface.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of a lensometer to determine the optical strength of eye glass lenses.

Concepts.definition: The use of a lensometer to determine the optical strength of eye glass lenses.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A structural template used as the basis for manufacturing three dimensional objects.

Concepts.definition: A structural template used as the basis for manufacturing three dimensional objects.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A method for determining the axial length of the eye.

Concepts.definition: A method for determining the axial length of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) combines the principles of ultrasound with the imaging performance of a microscope.  OCT uses infrared light waves that reflect off the internal microstructure within the biological tissues. The frequencies and bandwidths of infrared light are orders of magnitude higher than medical ultrasound signals, resulting in greatly increased image resolution, 8-25 times greater than any existing modality. In addition to providing high-level resolutions for the evaluation of microanatomic structures OCT is also able to provide information regarding tissue composition.

Concepts.definition: Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) combines the principles of ultrasound with the imaging performance of a microscope.  OCT uses infrared light waves that reflect off the internal microstructure within the biological tissues. The frequencies and bandwidths of infrared light are orders of magnitude higher than medical ultrasound signals, resulting in greatly increased image resolution, 8-25 times greater than any existing modality. In addition to providing high-level resolutions for the evaluation of microanatomic structures OCT is also able to provide information regarding tissue composition.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Methods for determining the topography or thickness of parts of the eye.

Concepts.definition: Methods for determining the topography or thickness of parts of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The use of optical coherence tomography to obtain images of the eye.

Concepts.definition: The use of optical coherence tomography to obtain images of the eye.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An assessment of ocular anatomy as well as any lesions that may be present within the eye that utilizes optical coherence tomography at frequencies of 10 MHz or higher.

Concepts.definition: An assessment of ocular anatomy as well as any lesions that may be present within the eye that utilizes optical coherence tomography at frequencies of 10 MHz or higher.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that combines spectral-domain optical coherence tomography with transverse confocal analysis, producing transverse images of retinal and choroidal layers at a specified depth.

Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that combines spectral-domain optical coherence tomography with transverse confocal analysis, producing transverse images of retinal and choroidal layers at a specified depth.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An eye examination technique that utilizes test objects with gradually increasing luminance that are positioned at fixed locations across the visual field to determine the threshold of visibility.

Concepts.definition: An eye examination technique that utilizes test objects with gradually increasing luminance that are positioned at fixed locations across the visual field to determine the threshold of visibility.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A device designed for continuous and touchless optical surface scanning of a patient's external surfaces for accurate patient positioning.

Concepts.definition: A device designed for continuous and touchless optical surface scanning of a patient's external surfaces for accurate patient positioning.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Planned; devised, contrived, or formed in design.

Concepts.definition: To devise, contrive, or form in design.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A sensor designed to measure the location or orientation of a person as compared to a reference point.

Concepts.definition: A sensor designed to measure the location or orientation of a person as compared to a reference point.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The process of transforming sets of image data from different times or perspectives into one coordinate system.

Concepts.definition: The process of transforming sets of image data from different times or perspectives into one coordinate system.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A graphical representation of the breathing pattern in a patient.

Concepts.definition: A graphical representation of the breathing pattern in a patient.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The representation of the stored pixel values of referenced images into some Real World value in defined units. This allows the capture of retrospectively determined mappings, e.g., for values that cannot be determined at the time of image acquisition and encoding.

Concepts.definition: The representation of the stored pixel values of referenced images into some Real World value in defined units. This allows the capture of retrospectively determined mappings, e.g., for values that cannot be determined at the time of image acquisition and encoding.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The process of assigning a label to every pixel in an image such that pixels with the same label share certain visual characteristics, allowing the image to be partitioned into multiple segments (e.g., boundaries, lines, curves).

Concepts.definition: The process of assigning a label to every pixel in an image such that pixels with the same label share certain visual characteristics, allowing the image to be partitioned into multiple segments (e.g., boundaries, lines, curves).

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A technique of determining the combination of spherical and cylindrical lenses that will result in the best-corrected visual acuity. The process involves the patient fixating at the Snellen Chart, while the clinician presents a variety of lenses and alters the power of the lenses in the trial frames according to the patient's subjective responses regarding improvements to their vision.

Concepts.definition: A technique of determining the combination of spherical and cylindrical lenses that will result in the best-corrected visual acuity. The process involves the patient fixating at the Snellen Chart, while the clinician presents a variety of lenses and alters the power of the lenses in the trial frames according to the patient's subjective responses regarding improvements to their vision.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An instrument designed to automate the process of staining specimens affixed to slides.

Concepts.definition: An instrument designed to automate the process of staining specimens affixed to slides.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A two-dimensional image file that stores information describing surface texture details across a specimen or image.

Concepts.definition: A two-dimensional image file that stores information describing surface texture details across a specimen or image.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Sharpness of vision, the ability to discern fine detail.

Concepts.definition: Sharpness of vision, the ability to discern fine detail.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A procedure that displays the electrical activity of the heart.

Concepts.definition: A procedure that displays the electrical activity of the heart.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 11/16/22 Created duplicate VM for ECG modality because existing  VM 2582146 did not have concept code and was reused by other SOs. mr

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ.

Concepts.definition: An imaging technique that uses a small dose of a radioactive chemical (isotope) called a tracer that can detect sites of cancer growth, trauma, infection or degenerative disorders. The tracer, which is either injected into a vein or swallowed, travels through the bloodstream to the target organ, and emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera and analyzed by a computer to form an image of the target organ.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Events, people, materials and activities uniquely defined by medical imaging.
ConceptualDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A comprehensive set of standards for communications between medical imaging devices, including handling, storing and transmitting information in medical imaging. It includes a file format definition and a network communication protocol._A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A comprehensive set of standards for communications between medical imaging devices, including handling, storing and transmitting information in medical imaging. It includes a file format definition and a network communication protocol.
A specific manner, characteristic, pattern of application or the employment of, any therapeutic agent or method of treatment, especially involving the physical treatment of a condition.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.origin: DICOM:Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine
ValueDomain.changeDescription: 10/6/10 released as part of content cleanup; definitions for VM still under review by IVI SMEs.  6/10/09 change status to draft mod as IVI SMEs provide definitions for value meanings.  6/1/09 new VD to change rep term from code to type per VCDE small group recommendation; kept as draft new during review to allow updates to modality type definitions.  10/9/08 - released post NCIA Interim Rpt Changes - enumerated values still need defintions from IVI WS SMEs.  9/17/07  VD versioned to support DICOM task utilizing IE & DICOM Attribute terms.  Needed for NCIA model load.

DataElement.changeDescription: 9/28/09 - typo in definition.  9/3/09 per VCDE direction, CDE given "Standard" status and moved to Data Standards folder.  8/5/09 updated short name.  6/18/09 added DICOM alt defs and names.  6/10/09 released with "draft mod" VD to allow update of value meaning descriptions by IVI SMEs during caBIG review.  6/1/09 created new CDE - new VD to change rep term from code to type per VCDE small group recommendation. VD kept draft new to permit addition of value definition by IVI workspace.  4/30/09 created to add "image" as an OC qualifier as part of the VCDE small group recommedation for the Equipment CDE set.
